$IREN Bull Thesis Based On $NVDA Earnings Call Part 1. Explosive AI Infrastructure Demand NVIDIA’s latest earnings call underscored an unprecedented surge in AI infrastructure spending. CEO Jensen Huang expects $3–4 trillion in AI infrastructure investment by 2030, calling this projection “fairly sensible for the next five years”. In fact, capital expenditures by the top four cloud providers have doubled to ~$600 billion annually in just two years, and Huang noted we are still “at the beginning of this buildout” across industries. This indicates a long runway of growth for companies that can supply data center capacity. Importantly, the demand isn’t confined to Big Tech – NVIDIA’s CFO highlighted broad drivers including cloud and enterprise AI adoption, government “sovereign AI” projects, and even physical AI/robotics, all requiring huge compute resources. In short, a worldwide AI data center build-out is underway, which forms a massive tailwind for infrastructure providers like $IREN.

content: NVIDIA $NVDA delivered another monster quarter top line ahead of estimates, margins near record highs, and guidance stronger than consensus. Yet the stock tanked. Why? Data Center revenue, the core AI engine, landed just shy of expectations No China chip sales factored in — a $2–5B swing if restrictions ease Valuation leaves zero room for “almost perfect” results The business is still running hot, but the selloff shows investors are now trading uncertainty, not earnings. Long-term AI story intact. Near-term: China + hyperscaler demand cycles will decide the tape.

$NVDA NETWORK REVENUE AT 98% Nvidia’s networking revenue hit $7.3B this quarter, up 98% YoY and 46% QoQ. Growth was fueled by NVLink compute fabric for GB200/GB300 systems, the ramp of XDR InfiniBand, and rising Ethernet adoption for AI workloads. Why it matters? This surge confirms the massive infrastructure build-out behind AI, and it directly lifts suppliers and ecosystem players. $ALAB benefits from PCIe connectivity and smart fabric controllers, $MRVL from custom ASIC and optical interconnects, and $AVGO from switching, optics, and high-speed networking chips.

BoA raises $NVDA price target to $235 (from $220) with buy rating: we believe it remains solidly positioned to maintain its 80%+ share in the fastest growing and most attractive global AI infrastructure buildout, along with industry leading 45%+ FCF margins and valuation at ~1x earnings growth rate (vs. S&P 500 index/Mag-7 peers at 2x+ PEG). China remains an uncertainty, but we expect non-China Rest of World (~$200bn in FY26E sales) to more than offset geopolitical headwinds in shipping to China, which we completely exclude from our model. ...NVDA’s “50% industry growth” suggests an earnings power of over $10/sh by CY27E (and perhaps $15 longer-term), in our estimation... we expect the uptrend to resume as investors revisit the solid fundamental outlook.

Thoughts on Nvidia Earnings Report $NVDA: Positive •Revenue $46.7B (+55.6% YoY, +6.1% QoQ), beating estimates by 2.7% •EPS $1.05 beat estimates by 5% •Data Center revenue $41.1B (+56.4% YoY) driven by Blackwell adoption •Automotive revenue $586M (+69.4% YoY), strongest SoC launch with Thor •Networking revenue $7.3B (+98% YoY), Spectrum X surpassed $10B annualized •Gaming revenue $4.3B (+48.9% YoY), boosted by Blackwell GPUs and RTX 5060 •U.S. revenue $23.5B (+80.2% YoY, 50.2% of total) •RPO $1.90B (+46.2% YoY) •Shareholder returns $10B; new $60B repurchase authorization •Q3’25 guidance: $54B revenue (+53.9% YoY), beating estimates by 4.1% Neutral •Professional Visualization revenue $601M (+32.4% YoY), cyclical exposure to CapEx •OEM & Other $173M (+96.6% YoY), small base •Taiwan revenue $8.5B (+48.6% YoY, 18.2% of total) •Other Countries $12.0B (+57.3% YoY, 25.6% of total) •SG&A/Revenue 2.4% (-0.4 PPs YoY) and R&D/Revenue 9.2% (-1.1 PPs YoY) show scale efficiency •SBC/Revenue 3%, stable with minor QoQ increase •Diluted shares down -1.3% YoY, supporting EPS leverage Negative •GAAP Gross Margin 72.4%, down -2.7 PPs YoY despite H20 inventory benefit •Operating Margin 60.8%, down -1.2 PPs YoY •Free Cash Flow Margin 28.8%, down -16.1 PPs YoY •China revenue $2.8B (-24.5% YoY, 5.9% of total), impacted by restrictions •Rising operating expenses from compute, infrastructure, and talent investments

Unpopular Thursday Morning Truth .... Don't MARRY your stocks, RENT them!!! $TSLA and $NVDA are the two biggest stocks I see people marrying. Marrying stocks is dangerous. If it works out it works out but TOO many people get blinded by the emotional attachment. They SIMPLY can't walk away Eventually like many marriages, someone cheats. The SEX got boring, or maybe you just grew apart. If you STAY fixated on it, you won't know when to cut your losses and you'll ride yourself back to ground zero. You didn't make a VOW at the altar to go the grave with it. So don't be so attached. Stocks move up and down, they move in cycles! What is HOT now will be cold, what is COLD now will be HOT

In $NVDA earnings, Jensen said that the winner in the next round will be the GPU that produces the most performance per watt. Upon further analysis: We see GB200NVL72 (Blackwell) generating 8.3 TFLOPS of performance per watt. But AMD's MI355X: In the real world though, it comes down to hardware + software. So here's how both the GPUs perform head-to-head in the DeepSeek R1 inference performance: Clearly, $AMD wins out on concurrency scaling - meaning, that it delivers more predictable, lower latency as the requests scale. As for NVIDIA, it struggles a lot with higher latency unless heavily optimized with TensorRT, and even then it’s not as efficient as MI300. This is still just one metric. I chose it for comparison since it's closer to real-life use cases. There's other metrics where Nvidia outdoes AMD, and they have their own merits.
